Carlin was NOT the first host of "Saturday Night Live".  The show was titled "NBC Saturday Night". ABC had a show that premiered 4 months before, starring Howard Cosell, called "Saturday Night Live".  The ABC show didn't last long, but the NBC show didn't change names until season 3.

Picky. Yes. But the NYT should have its facts straight.

To the folks wondering about ENDASH, my iPad with its case-keyboard will make three different lengths of dashes: a hyphen (-), an en-dash (–), and an em-dash (—). And none of these are an underscore (_); they all show up at the middle-of-letter level.

(From my font designer days) EM dash - a dash with its length equal to the width of a small “m” letter. (Alt-0150) EN dash - a dash with its length equal to the width of a small “n” letter. (usually half the width of an EM dash). (Alt-0151). There are width variations recently but in the classic font design - such rules apply (Helvetica, Garamond and so on). “minus” is shorter than both EN and EM dashes. Usage: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dash

"Anyway, the equivalent of H in the Greek alphabet is the letter ETA."

Oh dear, no! Not even numerically, η is the *seventh* letter of the Greek alphabet. And it is a vowel except in early ancient Greek!

I'm fascinated by the furore over EN DASH. I got it from crosses myself and never gave it another thought. 

Apparently in theory the matter of dashes is as complicated in Polish as it is in English. I just checked professional Polish websites, and I learned to my surprise that they recognize three types of dashes:

1. The longest one is called myślnik (literally, one related to thinking) or pauza (pause), and it - your em dash - is used in the middle of a sentence, eg. I did not cry — in fact, I laughed!

2. The półpauza (half-pause), your en dash, is slightly shorter than the myślnik, and it's used to denote number ranges, eg. 2023–2025 has so far been my period of activity on the NYT crossword comment board.

3. Finally, dywiz (a word meaning roughly the divider), also known as łącznik (the one who joins), is your hyphen, and it is used to connect words, like in a double-barrel surname, eg. Kowalska-Nowak.

Now, in practice, no normal Polish person makes any sort of distinction between the three types of dashes. Almost everybody uses dywiz in all contexts and to perform the functions of all of the dashes - probably simply because it's easiest to enter on a standard keyboard.

I was not taught about different dashes at school, despite having great teachers. That must have been because in the 80s and 90s we only studied cursive writing, not typing. Actually, despite 2 decades of publishing papers, I only learned about there being 3 rather than just 2 dashes today.

"An en dash (–) is a shorter mark used for ranges, connections, and replacing the word "to" (e.g., pages 10–12). An em dash (—) is a longer mark used for breaks, emphasis, and setting off information, acting like parentheses or commas to highlight additional details within a sentence."

Two thoughts, the first for columnist Deb A, who writes: "When you see a single letter as a clue, such as [H], the answer will usually be a letter in the Greek alphabet."  Okay, that's news to me.  Why not use the more familiar cluing, something like "H, in Athens"? Solvers who aren't familiar with very, very, very seldom-used convention will be in on the trick.

Second, when the answer is an abbreviation, isn't the clue to also have an abbreviation within, or a parenthetical (abbrev)? @john ezra
Moving into what would have been called a slum in post WWII Texas when I was 11 years old, I cut the ideological ties to my conservative (right wing, racist) family. My friends were Mexicans, Puerto Ricans, Italians, Jews, and my best friend was a Mexican girl who lived nearby in an unpainted, rickety house.  Her mother taught me to make flour tortillas but her brothers complained that when I made them into heart shapes and funny faces, they leaked,. She gave us money to buy wallpaper at the hardware store to re-paper Dolores' room, which we made into sort of a mess, but it was bright and we were proud of it.  

My brothers and sisters, who were many years older than I was, were outraged that I was spending all my time with "the lower classes," but fortunately they were too busy to interfere.  

It was an enriching and enlightening experience, and I have always been grateful to the kids I knew that they didn't hold my white face and Yankee accent against me. We were equals, and we never questioned it.

While both were popular mystery series for young readers, the Nancy Drew books were significantly more popular and had a far greater cultural impact than the Trixie Belden books.

Here is a breakdown of their popularity:

Sales and Longevity
Nancy Drew has been a publishing phenomenon since her debut in 1930. The original series, consisting of 56 books, has sold over 80 million copies and continues to be published today in various forms. The series has spawned numerous spin-offs, television shows, and films, cementing its place as an enduring franchise.

In contrast, the Trixie Belden series, which began in 1948, had a shorter run. The original series ended with 39 books, with sales that were a fraction of Nancy Drew's. While the books maintain a dedicated fan base, they never achieved the same level of mainstream success or market saturation.

Cultural Recognition
Nancy Drew is a global icon of juvenile fiction, with her name becoming synonymous with a young female detective. She is widely recognized, and her influence has been noted in the works of many contemporary authors. Trixie Belden, while beloved by her readers, did not reach the same level of cultural recognition.

"Minus" is a hyphen. That's a hyphen in your word "en-dash;" it's not as wide as the n.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight “The standard hyphen key on most keyboards produces a hyphen-minus character, which is a combination of the hyphen and minus sign”. One of the best references in typography comes - not unexpectedly - from Microsoft (their typography website is exceptional): https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/style-guide/punctuation/dashes-hyphens/ “Em dashes (—), en dashes (–), hyphens (-), and minus signs (−) aren't interchangeable symbols. Follow these guidelines to help you use them the right way, in the right places.“ To make this even more technical - in the initial ASCII notation there is no distinction between a hyphen and a minus; a single character, known as the hyphen-minus (ASCII 45 or U+002D), serves both purposes. In modern systems that support Unicode, a distinct "true minus" sign (U+2212 ) is available for mathematical contexts, designed to match the height and thickness of a plus sign, while the hyphen-minus is shorter and sits lower. So: EM dash - widest (as wide as a “m” letter) EN dash - in-between width (as wide as a “n” letter) Hyphen-minus - shorter than EN dash True minus - most of the time same width as hyphen minus - but sits higher from baseline than hyphen-minus - at the same height as the horizontal part of the plus sign. On the plain QWERTY keyboard - most of us use minus and hyphen with the same key.

@Andrzej I was in school starting in the 50s and through the 60s and no teacher ever even mentioned the kinds of dashes. I learned about them on the job as a sci-tech copywriter. The number of things we learn on the job is amazing. If you didn't work in publishing, it's not surprising that these kinds of dashes would not occur to you. The em dash—the longest one—is used to set off something that is not-quite parenthetical but the en dash signifies some kind of opposing relationship or a range (e.g., red–green or 3–8).

@Jim Cohoon Can I be a purist and say that you WROTE or CREATED some programming texts? I hate the practice of what I call "verbing"—changing a noun into a verb. For example if you create art, you would be arting. Ugh. It's true that we already have verbed words such as covering, which derived from to cover, which derived from a cover. But we shouldn't add to this mish-mash.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight that’s because until the advent of word processing and inkjet/laser printers only professional typesetters had access to the en and em dashes. In the olden days of typewriters (and the early days of word processing when printers had limited character sets) we used a double-hyphen to represent an em dash. (Except for those lucky enough to use an IBM Selectric, which had an em dash, along with being the best typewriter and keyboard ever.) Nowadays the double-hyphen has gone the way of the double space after a period.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
On the whole, I'm a prescriptivist rather than a descriptivist when it comes to usage. But my dear Ms Spaight, this battle was lost centuries ago. It is an entirely normal English process to change nouns to verbs. It is now a productive element in English. Join me in the rearguard against -izing to create verbs, a battle for which I still see some hope. Prioritize (glurk!) the possible.

"Too cute by half" is an idiom, roughly meaning "too smart for their own good". Here, a clue so clever that it's obscure or unsolvable or just tedious by the time you figure it out. Nothing to do with the NAm meaning of cute; it's a Britishism, where "cute" means sly or clever.
